Data Filtering profile

Selected Answer: B
Use Data Filtering profiles to prevent sensitive, confidential, and proprietary information from leaving your network. Predefined patterns, built-in settings, and customizable options make it easy for you to protect files that contain certain file properties (such as a document title or author), credit card numbers, regulated information from different countries (like social security numbers), and third-party data loss prevention (DLP) labels. 
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-policy/security-profiles/security-profile-data-filtering

questions.question_text:
Prior to a maintenance-window activity, the administrator would like to make a backup of only the running configuration to an external location.

What command in Device > Setup > Operations would provide the most operationally efficient way to achieve this outcome?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The Revert, Save, and Load operations all work with firewall co nfigurations local to the firewall. 
The Export operations transfer configurations as XML-formatted files from the firewall to the host running the web interface browser. From your local machine, you can save the files as configuration backups. 
The Import operations transfer XML configuration files from the host running the web interface browser to the firewall. The XML file can be loaded as the candidate configuration or even be committed to becoming the running configuration.
[Palo Alto Networks]

Selected Answer: A
A is correct:
Export Named Configuration Snapshot
This option exports the current running configuration, a candidate configuration snapshot, or a previously imported configuration (candidate or running). The firewall exports the configuration as an XML file with the specified name. You can save the snapshot in any network location. These exports often are used as backups. These XML files also can be used as templates for building other firewall configurations.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

Match each rule type with its example.

//IMG//

discussion.content: Looks like inter and interzone is intechanged.
Hi yes i agree on this as well intrazone only allows within a zone A and within zone B and not between them.

Answer is incorrect, here is correct answer: 
1. Create a policy with source zones A and B and destination zones A and B. The rule should apply to all traffic within zone a, all traffic within zone B, all traffic from Zone A to zone B, and all traffic from zone B to zone A.

2. Create a policy with source zones A and B. The rule will apply to all traffic within zone A and all traffic within zone B, but not to traffic between zones A and B.

3. Create a policy with source zone A and B and destination zones A and B. The rule would apply to traffic from zone A to zone B, and from zone B to zone A, but not traffic within zones A or B.

Intra

questions.question_text: What are the two default behaviors for the intrazone-default policy? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
By default, the firewall implicitly allows intrazone traffic (within a zone) and implicitly denies interzone traffic (between zones). 
By default, traffic allowed or denied by the implicit Security policy rules is not logged on the firewall.
[Palo Alto Networks]

Selected Answer: AD
by default the intrazone default does not log any traffic , we have to select it , then click on override and check log at session end in the action tab

Selected Answer: AD
Agree with SillyGoose123 (A and D)

Selected Answer: AD
By default, logging is disabled. Allow and Logging Disabled are the only two logical answers here

Selected Answer: AD
A D - Logging disabled by default

Selected Answer: AD
A, D. Logging is disabled by default on the intra and interzone rules.

Selected Answer: AD
Logging is disabled for default policies by default
A&D, Logging is disabled by default
AD - Logging is disabled by default
